text: We need to have a country and economy that reflects our good neighbor values of hospitality and building bigger tables instead of walls. Join the movement and Vote Matlock for US Senate in the Republican primary on August 4th. #MatlockforSenate #republicansocialism #kssen #ksleg #sunflowersocialism #todolist #goodneighbor #hospitality #buildabiggertable

Time to bring some optimism back to Kansas!  Things have been rough with the corporate takeover of agriculture, medical insurance profiteers, an ever more expensive housing stock, and austerity economics that pits us against each other.   This isn't the end of the story.  Kansas is a breadbasket.  As we look to transform our economy towards sustainability and taking care of each other, we can regain the hope and optimism of a state with room for everyone where people can contribute to creating a bounty that enriches our lives and our communities. We can build this Kansas together.  Let's get to work!   PS: let's respect, learn from, and stand with indigenous people this time!

Rural communities and small towns deserve quality healthcare, education, and housing, as well as access to healthy food.  Onaga is a town of just a few hundred with a new locally owned grocery store and a new health clinic. It was great to see a small town with some investment!  Also had the pleasure of talking to a 5th generation Kansas farmer and visiting the old family barn and picking up a few history lessons while talking about his vision for agricultural policy after the era of big corporate ag. #kssen #ksleg #kansas #agriculture #rural #smalltown #MatlockforSenate  @ Onaga, Kansas

Hello everybody, I need your help.   The Kansas GOP convention is this weekend and I have been excluded from the Senate primary debate.  I was not invited to participate, and our campaign team has attempted to reach out to numerous party affiliates who have not returned our correspondence.   Let the party leaders know that democracy is about letting the people decide, not party gatekeepers.  We need changes in this country like getting corporate money out of politics, and building a more robust democratic system.  Those who benefit from corporate donations shouldn't be the ones who decide who gets to speak to voters. As younger generations enter the political scene with different ideas, experiences, and approaches, they should be welcomed to participate, rather than silenced and excluded when it doesn’t fit the agenda of party bosses. If you believe that the Republican party should have a transparent process for including Senate debate participants, and should include smaller grassroots campaigns and outsider politicians, please do the following: 1. Sign the petition to get me on the debate stage: http://chng.it/ncXNkv2jbt 2. Share the petition, feel free to tag the @kansasrepublicanparty and use the hashtag #LetBrianDebate 3. Donate $20 to send a message that you stand with us bringing back the good neighbor Republican ethics! https://secure.anedot.com/brian-matlock-for-senate/donate

Appreciation post for my great friend and campaign treasurer @wmckain.  Wes has been a champ this week putting in the extra hours to get everything in order for our first quarterly FEC filing.  Find someone who loves you enough to figure out campaign finance and accounting so you don't go to #campaignjail I met Wes the first week I moved to KC KS 11 years ago. Since then he has been someone who challenges me to be my best, who I can dream big dreams with but is ready to hit the ground running on a project he believes in. We switch between our silliest and most sincere and convicted selves multiple times in a single hangout. I burn brighter with the joy and exuberance, vision, sincerity, and dedication of Wes in my life.  Pictured: us opening our campaign account right before filing, and me handing the pouch full of campaign receipts.  #kssen #ksleg #matlockforsenate #FEC #campaignfinance #bff #campaigntreasurer

We are hitting the road tomorrow to Southwest Kansas.  We prefer to stay in people's homes when possible to spend more time talking with real people and save money on this grassroots campaign. Do you know anyone SW Kansas who would be interested in hosting a candidate for US Senate?  We are looking for a place to stay Tuesday in Garden City/Dodge City or thereabouts.   Help us keep corporate money out of politics by putting up a politician in your home!

Ending homelessness is possible and cheaper than accepting it.  I have worked with the homeless a significant portion of my life.  It is a full time job surviving as a homeless person and they are way more likely to be successful and get a job when they have stable housing and counseling.  Let's do it!In Finland, the number of homeless people has fallen sharply. The reason: The country applies the “Housing First” concept. Those affected by homelessness receive a small apartment and counselling – without any preconditions. 4 out of 5 people affected thus make their way back into a stable life. And: All this is cheaper than accepting homelessness.

After some door knocking in the community, I had the pleasure of speaking alongside other Senate candidates at the Lyon county Republican precinct committee meeting.   I focused on my plan to create a job guarantee program that will create more meaningful jobs at a livable wage. It will stablize the economy to protect against unemployment during future recessions, and will allow us to make improtant changes as our economy is automated- either lowering the work week, transitioning to an economy more built on care work, creativity, and reclamations instead of throw away culture.  It will importantly also allow us to transition workers freed from inefficient jobs to meaningful work. The immense efficiency gains from medicare for all (eliminating private insurance companies & most of billing/collections departments) or transitioning away from fossil fuels should be seen as opportunities to put people to work on the things that matter to us. Let's get to work!  @ Emporia, Kansas

Kansas was founded as a free state, a safe haven for the enslaved trying to escape their oppressors. Freedmen, Wyandots, and white settlers worked together to ensure slavery would not prevail in Kansas. When I launched my campaign, I held the event at the historic Quindaro Townsite, which had been a stop on the underground railroad to help slaves escape from the slave state across the river. When I speak of Kansas values, this is the spirit I am invoking, and to me, the Kansas spirit of a safe and welcoming land lives on to this day. Today, we must all continue to work together to see that our immigrant friends and neighbors are able to feel safe and prosper. Personally, I have many friends in the immigrant community. When I considered what my immigration policy would entail, I reached out directly to those who have had to interact with our immigration system. My immigration policy is currently, and will continue to be, informed by their needs. In the spirit of the Kansas value of lending a hand to our neighbors: ICE needs to be abolished or at least seriously defunded and restructured. The main function of the organization today is to round up folks who are already living here, and that is not consistent with Kansas values. Unauthorized border crossing should be amended from a criminal offense to a civil one. My entire domestic policy prioritizes Kansans who are struggling, and I acknowledge that immigrants and refugees are struggling so much in their respective countries of origin that they are willing to uproot their lives to find something better for themselves and their families. This does not sound like a crime to me. DACA needs to be extended to the new generation of young immigrants who currently have no protection from deportation. If you came here as a child, if you grew up and went to school here, then you’re as much a part of this country as I am, and our policy needs to reflect that. You should have a painless path to citizenship immediately available to you. The Public Charge rule should be abolished. As a socialist, I reject the premise of a system that determines the merits of a person based on their economic status. The Public Charge rule is openly classist and it is time we see it for what it is. There is currently a bond imposed for folks seeking asylum. This means if you’re fleeing danger in your country of origin, you must pay the US Government $1500 to avoid immediate deportation. This is not how asylum should work. The United States championed asylum laws after WWII, and now we impose a ransom on those who are not safe in their home states.  This, also, is in consistent with Kansas values. It should be assumed that asylum seekers are not in the best financial situation, and we should take pride in our ability to support and protect them.  This is just a sampling of my immigration policy. This is an issue that is extremely important to me and I will continue to be a champion for compassionate policies that help folks rather than hurting them.

Back at the state Capitol building for the healthcare rally put on by the @kspoorpeoplescampaign @kansasinterfaithaction and others to stand for healthcare solutions that work for the many left behind in our communities.  Guaranteed Healthcare allows for people to get healthcare and get back to work rather than avoid treatment as conditions worsen. It allows those with mental health concerns to get help rather than struggle in silence , it allows entrepreneurs, artists, students and other risk takers to have peace of mind while they pursue their dreams. We all get sick and are at risk for unexpected health problems and would benefit from the peace of mind that comes from knowing we are covered.  We benefit from the freedom of choice of choosing providers without in-network or in-state requirements.    I will fight for #MedicareForAll when I get congress to save money, increase provider choice and give peace of mind. @ Kansas State Capitol

All of my Republican opponents in the primary are lining up to see who can be the most pro-Trump candidate despite Trump's lack of popularity in Kansas, and this is by and large why I'm going to win. Stripping healthcare away from poor people and scapegoating immigrants are not Kansas values, and Trumpism continues to be unpopular with the hundreds of thousands of Good Neighbor Republicans in Kansas.  In the 2016 Presidential primary, only 23% of Kansas Republicans voted for Trump to be their nominee, and I don't believe that support has increased since, as indicated by the 2018 Gubernatorial race where Laura Kelly wiped the floor with Trump stooge Kris Kobach.  Kansas Republicans understand that we've had decades of rising costs while wages have remained stagnant, and they're looking for someone who is going to offer real-world solutions that make their lives better, rather than the scapegoating and finger pointing that is happening instead.  The Republican establishment no longer represents lifelong Republicans like myself. I not only plan to win this primary, but I intend to prove that the direction the party has gone does not represent the Good Neighbor Republicans who truly want a better way forward.

When folks in this country are unemployed, it isn’t because there isn’t enough work to be done. As we look around our communities, there are endless projects to take on – dilapidated housing, care work of every type, beautification of our town squares, increasing access to healthy foods – but the money to start these projects always seems just out of reach as our local governments scramble to find money to keep the basic infrastructure in place. Meanwhile, Federal money is being used to shower already wealthy corporations and pay for endless wars. It is time we put that money to work in our communities. A Federally funded, locally administered job guarantee would put the resources in our hands to prioritize the things we need done and build an economy that works for us. The local administration of this program will focus on the democratization of our workforce. Sometimes when we tell people about the job guarantee, we hear “what about the people who don’t want to work?”. We believe that people DO want to work, but there currently aren’t positions that fit their physical, mental, or socioeconomic needs. In urban areas, good paying jobs are highly competitive. Even with a Bachelor’s degree, finding a job can itself be a full-time job. Furthermore, finding a position that fits your skills AND pays enough to afford your exorbitant student loan debt is next to impossible. In low-income urban areas, there are often no jobs available.  Capital has a tendency to concentrate, and that is exactly what happened in our urban areas. As our cities began to suburbanize, corporations moved out of low-income neighborhoods so they could be closer to the hip neighborhoods that were attracting college educated young people. This disinvestment has especially caused Black neighborhoods to be without decent paying jobs. Folks often work 2 or 3 minimum wage jobs just to keep the lights on. Rural towns around Kansas mostly sprung to life in the mid-late 1800s, as there was money to be made in fossil fuels, minerals, or farming. Many of those towns were left to die after big industry stripped the resources from the ground and moved on to the next opportunity. Farming towns have fared a little better than oil, coal, lead, and zinc towns, but we have started to see a shift to less prosperity in those communities as well, as our farming system continues to commodify. Folks in our rural communities often drive 30+ miles per day to find work in a plant or factory in the nearest commerce district, only to then have their tax dollars are extracted by the company who is incorporated in another state or country. Over the next few months, we look forward to talking with folks throughout Kansas communities to further discuss what types of jobs might be appealing to them as we begin to re-envision our economy. It is essential we start having these conversation and understand what the infrastructure should look like. We know our economy ebbs and flows, and the current growth cycle will eventually come to a halt. In a recession, when many lose their jobs, a job guarantee would make sure people can continue contributing and earning. Once the economy gets back to normal, the private companies can hire back. Rather than be unemployed during rough times, we can keep working on the things we decide are important in our communities. These jobs will pay a living wage. If the jobs are worth doing, they are worth paying people enough to live on. This will help stabilize prices to avoid both deflation and inflation. Providing a price floor at a living wage and maintaining stable employment will provide fewer fluctuations in the economy, and the set wage will avoid bidding up prices against the private sector. The job guarantee will allow for a just transition of the economy. When fossil fuel energy workers are displaced by the transition to sustainable energy, and insurance and billing workers are displaced by Medicare for All, the job guarantee ensures that those people continue to have meaningful jobs in our communities. It’s time we turn our Unemployment Offices into Employment Offices!

We know the difference between the type of politicians who get contributions from defense contractors vs. those who get contributions from military personnel.   There are plenty in both parties who go to war on cheap suspicions and political points or for control of resources and spare no expense in their military campaigns. They are suddenly 'broke' when our veterans come back, and lose their humanitarian hearts when refugees of war come to our doorsteps.  The candidates we need and that the mitary personnel trust are the ones who take seriously the cost of human lives and take great lengths to avoid armed conflicts, and are most committed to taking care of our veterans and of refugees of war torn countries.   I applaud Bernie that he has shown himself committed to avoid putting our family members lives on the line in endless conflict and most supportive of taking care of vets when they get back home. We need more in politics who do likewise.

Small towns and rural people often defy the expectations and stereotypes city-folk put on them.  I had the pleasure of attending a city council meeting in Iola KS where they were discussing changing the racist name of “Coon Creek” to its old name “Small Creek."  People came together to make the case and support the change. @autley26 did the research to clearly establish that the name was indeed based on racism not racoons.  ACC students gathered 100 signatures, and the clear voices of black community leaders led others to change their minds and support the name change. +/-8 people spoke during the public discussion. It was so encouraging to see Black & white, young & old community members speaking in one accord. Here are a few representative highlights: "In Iola we're just better than that" "Why not change it and do what's right. We're better than that."  "I changed my opinion 100%" "I think it should be changed to Bass Creek [after Dr. Bass, a black Dr in the civil war (I think)]"  "You tell me: what should we [ACC students of color] expect?... or a city moving forward with intention and inclusivity?"  "We need to be willing to step forward and say we are better than that... we could make it into a positive. It just seems like the right thing to do" - former city council member "Just b/c you live in a small town you're not a hick....ppl look down on us... let the people vote on it."  Historian on behalf of Rosemary Bass (wrote a persuasive article for paper): "She always felt the name of the creek was a racial slur and would like it changed" Council member: I applaud you who came out tonight. As Iolans every one of us should want this changed. There are people online who said this change is desired b/c this generation is soft: shame on them. Name change unanimously passed!  @ Iola, Kansas

This is amazing work. The Green New Deal must be driven by the needs and vision of local communities.  There is plenty of work to be done in our communities and we have the most knowledge of those needs and what we are most passionate and motivated to work on. It is time the government stops opting to dump the money and decisionmaking in the hands of greedy corporations.  #GreenNewDeal #kssen #localcontrol #republicansocialism #MatlockforSenate#GreenNewDeal song by my friend Allen Schwartz at our #GND community brainstorming session at the Newark Think Tank on Poverty. Watch the livestream on Real Progressives. It was amazing to see the community come together and brainstorm more than 100 different GND job categories needed in #Newark #Ohio in less than one hour. How to pay for it #MMT (Part II), and how to communicate this to your neighbors (Part III) will take place in January 2020. Stay tuned! It's the GND y'all!

SE Kansas tour continued! Interview @ Chanute Tribune with a hardball reporter 💪 (talked a lot of issues that were outside the range of our prepared talking points) and had coffee and a delightful convo with a few community members at a nonprofit community run coffee shop and concert venue: FireEscape Coffeehouse. Chanute has the highest rate of kids in foster care and they have 80 foster kids hang out every Friday and Saturday.  It is run by some good neighbors who are pitchin in to meet needs in that community. Also my dear wife Adrianne LOST HER MIND when she found out her teenage hero Christian Music Superstar Jennifer Knapp was from Chanute and had helped get that venue going (Adri has asked twice since then how/when we will get to meet @jenniferknappmusic 😂) We then had a great meeting with the SEK-CAP team about housing and childcare needs in SE Kansas  @ Cignetcoffee. "You can't talk about economic development if you aren't talking about childcare and housing! " @ Chanute, Kansas

Iola! Great talking to Thrive Allen County about their work and community needs, ran into an adorable groups of kids at Southwind Bikes and hid from the cold at the Around the Corner Coffee Shop. @ Iola, Kansas
Had a great meeting with the new Mayor of Neodesha and explored the community.  Hope to make it back soon for some door knocking and chatting with neighbors!  @ Neodesha, Kansas

Had our first newspaper interview at The Morning Sun in Pittsburg Kansas.  Thanks for having me out to talk about getting past the partisan tit-for-tat to get to work solving problems in our communities!  #pittsburgks #republicansocialism #MatlockforSenate  @ Pittsburg, Kansas

I have been to many other countries and have been overwhelmed by the hospitality, acceptance, inclusion, and patience people have shown me.  It breaks my heart to think those folks would not be shown the same here in America.

I spent a lot of time feeling overwhelmed about the environmental, social, and economic problems that face us. It feels hopeless when we try to do it alone. Seeing the number of young people who are investing so much of their time and energy in to change gives me hope. The @sunrisemvmtkc team in particular has awakened a new excitement and optimism in me. I am so inspired by y'all!  We are gonna win. ✊ #GreenNewDeal  @ Kansas City City Hall

source: Matlock for Kansas,Global Institute for Sustainable Prosperity - GISP
shared_from: Global Institute for Sustainable Prosperity - GISP
text: The Global Institute for Sustainable Prosperity is an institute I was a research assistant with during my graduate education in economics.  They are doing incredibly important work to measure the actual quality of jobs in our economy to understand people's struggles even when the official unemployment rate is low.New Job Quality Index numbers are out now. Of 245,000 jobs added last month, 47.76% of those jobs were low-quality. This is down from 83.31% seen in October which is likely due to GM workers returning to work from their strike.  #JQI #Jobs #JobQualityIndex #Unemployment

We are 1/10 of 1% to our fundraising goal of $6 million! Yes, unfortunately that's the kind of money it is going to take to defeat both the neo-liberals who are stripping resources from our communities and the fascists who are punishing low-income people and minorities. We understand that many of you cannot afford to donate more than a few bucks, and we appreciate anything you're able to offer. For anyone who is able to donate a little more, please do so on behalf of all those who can't. We won't be taking any PAC money because we need you to know that we are going to fight for low- and middle-income people, so it's on you, The People, to keep this campaign viable. Here's the link to donate to Brian Matlock for Senate: https://secure.anedot.com/brian-matlock-for-senate/donate

I have been a part of this problem both by things I have done and things I didn't have the courage to do. I am still learning. I am so grateful for the unearned patience, mentoring, and leadership I have had from so many women and people of color.  I commit to continue to listen, learn, and become more brave to show up for y'all like you have for me.   We are stronger together.
